## Project Summary

### Description
The project aims to implement energy-efficient Improved Cook Stoves (ICS) in Maharashtra state, India, as a measure to reduce greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions and promote sustainable cooking practices. By replacing traditional stoves with ICS, the project seeks to enhance energy efficiency and decrease emissions associated with cooking fuel consumption.

### Technologies/Measures
The core technology involved in the project is the adoption of Improved Cook Stoves (ICS) to replace traditional, less efficient stoves. ICS are designed to optimize fuel combustion, resulting in reduced emissions and improved cooking efficiency.

### Location
The project is situated in Maharashtra state, India, where the deployment of energy-efficient ICS will directly impact household cooking practices and contribute to environmental sustainability efforts in the region.

### GHG Emission Reduction
Through the implementation of ICS, the project is expected to generate significant GHG emission reductions. By transitioning from non-renewable biomass to energy-efficient ICS, the project will reduce emissions stemming from cooking fuel consumption and enhance the overall efficiency of cooking processes.

### Scenario Before Implementation
Prior to the project initiation, the prevailing scenario involved the continued use of non-renewable biomass for cooking purposes, leading to higher emissions and inefficiencies in the cooking process.

### Estimates
The project is estimated to achieve substantial annual average GHG emission reductions totaling 2,297,154 tCO2e. Over the 7-year crediting period, the project is projected to achieve a total reduction of 16,080,078 tCO2e, showcasing the long-term environmental benefits of the initiative.
